row.hikeInfo:
This vast badlands is a part of the BLM "Bisti/De Na Zin Wilderness Area", and De Na Zin forms the eastern part of the block. It is reached from US550 on CR7500 - also seen as Is7023 (Indian Service Road) on some maps. From US550, take the gravel road straight for 11.1 miles to a marked parking area on the north side of the road.

There is no trail in the De Na Zin, although a trail segment leads from the parking area down into the canyon - a rather small elevation level change, with an easy descent. From there, follow the wash west as it descends and eventually merges with the larger De Na Zin wash. All along the wash, petrified wood is strewn along and in the banks, ranging from large logs and trunks to smaller broken pieces. As if that were not enough, wildly colorful hills and banks proliferate, with hoodoos appearing now and then, both high and low. The wash can be followed for an indeterminate length, with the opportunity to explore side canyons and arroyos flowing in. This area is hard to describe given the variety of topological features, and the hike can lead you almost anywhere!
row.refs: 5^b^100 Hikes in New Mexico^, by Craig Martin^b^New Mexico's Wilderness Areas^, by Bob Julyan^w^http://www.americansouthwest.net/new_mexico/de-na-zin/wilderness-area.html^American Southwest^w^http://www.blm.gov/nm/st/en/prog/blm_special_areas/wilderness_and_wsas/wilderness_areas/bisti.html^BLM Site^w^http://www.hanksville.org/voyage/misc/denazin.html^Hanksville.org

row.hikeInfo:
The Bisti Badlands is considered to be one of the most scenic areas of the southwest - rightfully so! Located about 40 miles south of Farmington off 371, access is provided by dirt road at a well-marked turn-off between mile markers 70 and 71. The badlands is part of a vast wilderness area, and is loaded with bizarre and twisted rock sculptures, accentuated by a striking mix of color. Many of the more well-known features have been assigned interesting names, so it is well to plan in advance to see these, as the area has no trails and is open in every direction. Oftentimes the features are quite a distance apart.

Be prepared, as the badlands is fully exposed to the sun, and carrying water, along with a reliable GPS unit, is advised. The best time to visit is in the fall, when summer's heat has faded. Winter can be brutal, and spring is often very windy in the southwest. It is difficult to present images that impart the solitude and vastness of the place, and photographing the scenes can be a challenge owing to the direct sun. Check out the photographic work in the references for an excellent and thoughtful presentation of hoodoo images at the badlands.
row.refs: 10^p^Wonderland, A Photographer's Journey into the Bisti^,by Eduardo Fuss^b^100 Hikes In New Mexico^, by Craig Martin^b^New Mexico's Wilderness Areas^, by Bob Julyan^b^New Mexico Journey Guide^, by John Kramer & Julie Martinez^b^Hiking New Mexico^, by Laurence Parent^w^http://www.americansouthwest.net/new_mexico/bisti_badlands/^American Southwest^w^http://www.blm.gov/nm/st/en/prog/blm_special_areas/wilderness_and_wsas/wilderness_areas/bisti.html^BLM Site^w^https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bisti/De-Na-Zin_Wilderness^Wikipeida^w^https://farmingtonnm.org/listings/bisti-de-na-zin-wilderness/^FarmingtonNM.org^l^http://www.thewave.info/BistiBadlandsCode/Map.html^The Wave

row.tipsTxt: The trail diverging from the Piedra Lisa Trail which is the Waterfall Canyon Trail is not conspicuous, and not officially maintained. From the trailhead of Piedra Lisa, there is a slow ascent prior to dropping down to a streambed which crosses the Piedra Lisa Trail. This occurs near a marker for the Piedra Lisa Trail. There is another trail, proceeding straight from that point, which is the Fletcher Trail, and has a worn-out marker. The Waterfall Canyon Trail proceeds up the streambed to the right (south - see red flag on map). There are warnings in the references about bushwacking to reach the waterfall, but there are multiple waterfalls upstream, and the first (subject of this hike), is well-worn, requiring only a slight scramble downward to see the 15-foot "rooster tail". To continue further in order to see upstream watefalls will require additional scrambling and perhaps some bushwacking.
row.hikeInfo: Beginning from the Piedra Lisa Trailhead parking lot, views of the Sandia are most impressive. From here, looking northwest, a pleasant view of the Rincon Ridge and its valley can be seen, while looking west, there is a clear view of the Albuquerque Volcanoes. To the east/northeast are the Sandia landmarks: the shield, the prow, and the needle. The Piedra Lisa Trailhead proceeds across the dirt road (Forest Rd 333D) and up into the hill running parallel to the road. Please read the Trail Tips to find the way up to Waterfall Canyon. It is a lovely cascade of about 15 feet, surrounded by small rock cliffs and vegetation. The trail is easy, and marked as "easy-moderate" only due to the fact that you will have to scramble down a small set of boulders to get a good view of the waterfall. You can also scramble up for a view, but you won't get as close. The trail is not long, nor steep, and makes for a rewarding hike.
row.refs: 4^b^60 Hikes Within 60 Miles - Albuquerque^, by The Stephen Ausherman^b^Sandia Mountain Hiking Guide [reference only]^, by Mike Coltrin^w^http://www.sandiahiking.com/trailguide.html^Site accompanying above book^a^https://www.trails.com/tcatalog_trail.aspx?trailid=XMR022-007^Trails.com

row.tipsTxt: The trail is described as a "balloon" (aka "lollipop") trail that proceeds out from the trailhead a distance, and then makes a short loop. The return portion of the loop traverses the Bike & Hike trail, is paved and is somewhat busy. A better option is to make the trip an "out-and-back" hike to the endpoint near the Montano Road bridge, and avoid the popular paved trail.
row.hikeInfo: The Rio Grande Nature Center (RGNC) is home not only to informative nature walks, events, gift shop, and bird viewing room (with floor-to-ceiling glass), but also to several short hikes in the Rio Grande Bosque. This particular hike is called the "Aldo Leopold Trail", dedicated to the efforts of the wildlife conservationist. While the trail is easy and flat, the views of the "Aldo Leopold Forest" (part of the Bosque), and the Rio Grande are lovely. The walk is peaceful and perhaps less frequently traveled than the other trails at the Nature Center owing to its longer length.
row.refs: 4^b^60 Hikes Within 60 Miles: Albuquerque^, by Stephen Ausherman^b^Best Hikes Near Albuquerque^, by JD Tanner & Emily Ressler-Tanner^w^https://www.cabq.gov/parksandrecreation/parks/prescription-trails/87107/aldo-leopold-trail^City of Albuquerque^w^https://prescriptiontrails.org/trail/19/aldo-leopold-trail/^Prescription Trails

row.hikeInfo: The Cerrillos Hills State Park abuts BLM land to its west, thereby forming a hiking opportunity that is not in the park proper. The book reference listed below shows it as an "Exploratory Route", and actually there are some other trails that can be explored branching off from the hike shown on the map. Regardless, the trail ascends slowly up an arroyo and into the canyon areas of Cerrillos Hills. A spur trail, north of the loop, provides access to an old mine shaft and Grand Central Mountain, which allegedly provides some great area views, including the escarpment of La Bajada. The scenery is quite different than that of the State Park, so the hike makes for a rather different excursion. The trailhead access is an unmarked dirt road, just off of CR57 (the dirt road can be seen using the Satellite View on google maps).
row.refs: 2^b^60 Hikes Within 60 Miles: Albuquerque^, Stephen Ausherman^n^No online references for the exploratory routes

row.hikeInfo:
El Morro National Monument is known for its inscriptions of those who passed before, as it was located on an ancient east-west trail. It also offered a precious commodity - water - and was hence a necessary spot to visit when traveling through the area. The rock inscriptions range from those created by ancient Indians to those added by the more modern Spanish Conquistadors. One of the more famous Spaniards is Don Juan Onate, the first governor of the territory. Later on, a survey team from the Union Pacific Railroad (UPR) passed through and left its mark.

Owing to the convenient source of water, an ancient pueblo was built on top of the towering rock overlooking the pool, and its ruins are now part of the attraction. It is unclear how long the ruins were in use, and archeologists believe that Indians were living in the area prior to building the pueblo. Like many of the southwest ancient ruins, the people left somewhere around 1200-1300BC.
row.refs: 3^b^New Mexico Journey Guide^, by Jon Kramer & Julie Martinez^w^https://www.nps.gov/elmo/index.htm^National Park Service: El Morro^w^https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/El_Morro_National_Monument^Wikipedia

row.hikeInfo:
The Rio Grande Nature Center is a New Mexico State Park offering diverse activities and a number of short hikes. The Visitor Center offers the opportunity to sit in a ceiling-to-floor glass viewing room overlooking a backwater of the Rio Grande where numerous waterfowl and other birds live or pass through. A microphone adds a cacophony of bird sounds to the viewing room. The park offers guided birding events and other family activities.
There are three short loop hikes available on the opposite shore and are accessed via a footbridge. The all wind through the bosque adjacent to the river and provide numerous opportunities for bird watching. The trails are all level and well-groomed so that almost anyone can walk them. There is a minimal parking fee unless you belong to the "Friends of the Rio Grande Nature Center".
row.refs: 2^w^http://www.emnrd.state.nm.us/SPD/riograndenaturecenterstatepark.html^NM State Parks^w^http://www.rgnc.org/^Friends of the RGNC

row.hikeInfo:
This Sandoval County-owned property is somewhat remote, but the trip is well worth the travel. Generally, depending on which direction the Open Sapce is approached from, an all-wheel drive vehicle is safer, especially when bad weather precedes the hike. A spacious, new all-gravel parking lot has been provided at the trail head.
From the parking lot, the trail provides a 2+ mile loop around the edge of a mesa overlooking the canyon, which is formed by multiple criss-crossing arroyos and stream beds. From the loop trail, a branch descends gradually into the shallow canyon, and winds around the canyon floor following the contours formed by the arroyos. The trails are all well-groomed and easy to follow with gradual elevation changes. A highlight of the loop is the view of multiple mountain ranges from the mesa edge: the east side of the Sandias, the San Pedros, the Ortiz and Cerrillos Hills. Since the trail is exposed, it might not be the best hike for the summer months. As the site is somewhat remote, the traffic is generally low.
row.refs: 4^b^60 Hikes Within 60 Miles of Albuquerque^, by Stephen Ausherman^w^https://www.cabq.gov/parksandrecreation/open-space/lands/sandoval-county-open-space^City ofAlbuquerque^g^https://www.meetup.com/hiking-204/events/54383802/^Albuquerque Meetup Group^a^https://www.trails.com/tcatalog_trail.aspx?trailid=XMR022-020^Trails.com

row.tipsTxt: The Picacho Peak Trail is actually a part of the Dale Ball Trail System of Santa Fe. Being close to Santa Fe makes the hike accessible to locals. That means parking can be a problem, especially at the Atalaya Upper Trailhead (off Camino de Cruz Blanca) where space is quite limited.
row.hikeInfo:
The authors did this as a one-way (two-car) hike starting at the Atalaya Upper Trailhead and ending at the Canyon Road trailhead. On the way down towards Canyon Road, they made a detour off the main trail that is flagged on the Actual Hike map. This hike can also be done as an "out-and-back" hike from either of the two trailheads, the distance to the top being roughly equal regardless of the starting point.
There are numerous nice views of the Santa Fe valley as you go. From the summit of Picacho, the view extends north along the Sangre de Cristos, southeast to Atalaya Ridge, south to Sun and Moon Mountains, and southwest to the Sandia. The trail is well-defined and ascends at a reasonable rate, a bit steeper near the summit.
row.refs: 3^b^Day Hikes In The Santa Fe Area [8th Ed.] (See Dale Ball Trails - South)^, The Northern New Mexico Group of the Sierra Club^l^http://highdesertdirt.blogspot.com/2013/07/climbing-ladder-on-picacho-peak.html^High Desert Dirt^l^https://www.innonthealameda.com/2010/03/the-dale-ball-trails-picacho-peak/^Inn on the Alameda

row.tipsTxt: The Bike Trails are actually suitable for biking, hiking, and equestrian activity, depending on the difficulty chosen. Each trail segment is indicated by a number - but unfortunately, many of the signs indicating the trail segment are now missing. The authors mistakenly took the Dragon's Back Trail, but were more than happy with the scenery it provided. When attempting to re-connect with the intended hike, some precarious trails were taken, first descending into the valley, and then scaling it part-way up on narrow, steep paths along the way, which were actually dangerous. It is highly recommended that you carefully plan your route prior to embarking on it.
row.hikeInfo: The ample gravel parking lot off of Cabezon Road provides access to the trailhead. It is well-marked and easy to find. What is not easy is finding the desired trail segments (see Trail Tips, above). This hike ended up traversing part of the Dragon's back, which provided fantastic panoramic views of the area - from the Jemez Mountains and part of the Sangre de Cristos, to Cabezon Peak, and parts of the Ojito Wilderness area. The authors descended into the colorful valley for part of the trip which led to other great views. Plan the route carefully, and pay special attention to forks which may be un-marked. The area is well worth a visit!
row.refs: 2^b^60 Hikes Within 60 Miles of Albuquerque^, Stephen Ausherman^w^https://www.mtbproject.com/trail/207597/dragons-back^Mountain Bike Site

row.tipsTxt: As with other hikes on Chino Mesa, access is via FR24 - a poorly maintained dirt road, with rocks, close-in junipers and cactus, and other hazards. A high-clearance, 4-wheel drive vehicle is a must. As with the Pinabete Tank hike, take NM62 off of Caja Del Rio Road, and watch for a fork. Take the right branch. This hike however branches off to the left before Pinabete Tank, and stopped near a powerline road, which became to difficult to traverse by vehicle. Good maps of the area are highly recommended.
row.hikeInfo: This hike follows the powerline road down towards the rim of the canyon. At some point the authors descended in an attempt to find a way down to the Rio Grande. Although unsuccessful, the views were well worth the trip. As with Pinabete Tank, there are no references for this hike, and there are no trails.
row.refs: 1^n^No References Found

row.tipsTxt: This hike in the Chino Mesa area is also accessed via the unmaintained FR24 off of NM62. Travel on FR24 requires a high-clearance 4-wheel drive vehicle, and some areas are boxed in by juniper and cactus, or traverse very rocky patches. The tracks are deeply rutted and require careful navigation. This hike begins far earlier on FR24 than Chino Mesa or Pinabete Tank, but the branch off of FR24 can also be traveled a distance, to be determined by the driver.
row.hikeInfo: There are no trails in this area, though the early part of the hike can follow the double-track "road" towards the hills. There is also a verbal description in the book reference listed below, but the authors had some trouble mapping the description to the actual hike. Hence, this hike, in part, was an experience in bush-whacking and was often based on curiosity about some of the volcanic features: cones, plugs, and vents. Throughout the hike, the views of the volcanic plateau are extensive and interesting. There has been a significant geological study of the area - Montoso Peak - for which a link has been provided in the references. Since the travel on FR24 is significantly less than the Chino Mesa or Pinabete Tank hikes, it can provide an accessible an interesting hike and an adventure limited only by your desire to explore.

row.hikeInfo: The Piedra Lisa Trail, located on FR333 off of Tramway Blvd, just past the Juan Tabo Picnic area and La Luz Trailhead, is nestled in the Rincon Valley. There are other areas in Albuquerque also called Piedra Lisa, and this one is marked "Piedra Lisa-south" for reasons unknown. From the ample parking area, there are pleasant and scenic views of the Sandias and also Rincon Ridge, which sits immediately west of the Sandia. The Piedra Lisa trail is well marked and from the parking lot, parallels FR333 a short while before dropping into a trail juncture of Piedra Lisa, Waterfall Canyon, Fletcher Trail, and Movie Trail. Piedra Lisa continues left of these other trailheads and essentially straight across the arroyo there. From here the trail goes up, non-stop, to the top of Rincon Ridge, with great views of both the Sandia and Rincon Ridge along the way. The trail continues past the ridge top towards Placitas for those who wish to go further, but the authors returned to the starting point from the top.
row.refs: 5^b^Sandia Mountain Hiking Guide^, Mike Coltrin^w^http://www.explorenm.com/hikes/PiedraLisa/^Explore New Mexico^w^http://www.sandiahiking.com/trailguide.html#piedralisasouth^Sandia Mountain Hiking Guide^a^http://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/new-mexico/piedra-lisa-trail-135^AllTrails^w^http://www.summitpost.org/piedra-lisa-trail-no-135-south-trailh/166172^SummitPost

row.tipsTxt:
The access to the hike, although owned by BLM, has what appears to be a locked gate. In actuality, at the time of this visit, the chain on the gate was simply hooked and easily undone to allow access beyond. The distance from the road to the hike start point is rather small, so it is not required to park beyond the gate if locked.

The San Pedros were a part of the old Gold Rush and hence have many abandoned mines throughout. These are generally not closed off, so do not attempt to enter them.
row.hikeInfo: The San Pedros are a smaller range northeast of Albuquerque, but provide some unique vistas of the surrounding terrain - from the back of the Sandia (Eastern slopes) to the Ortiz, and beyond. From the entrance gate, there are multiple double-track jeep trails proceeding in various directions. This hike attempted to follow a route provided in the references to the top of Cerro Columbo. At the beginning of the hike, prior to the diverging trails, is a large and interesting field of obsidian which appears to have been partially disrupted by mining or other efforts. The jeep trails wander throughout the area, so the authors did some off-trail exploring to gain access to the top of Cerro Columbo. From the top, other parts of the San Pedros are visible: South Mountain, Lone Mountain, and other unnamed peaks. The trail begins off of NM344 not far from NM14 near Golden.
row.refs: 2^b^60 Hikes Within 60 Miles of Albuquerque^, Stephen Ausherman^a^https://www.trails.com/tcatalog_trail.aspx?trailid=XMR022-021^Trails.com

row.hikeInfo: There is a trail from the Parking Lot / Camping Area that proceeds up to the top of Diablo Canyon, which the authors failed to discover until later on (see hike map). The trail is slightly steep as it ascends, and there are no trails on top. The top of Diablo Canyon is not really a (flat) mesa, as it has many rolling humps with steep drops off its edge. The so-called mesa forms something of a rough circle, and the views which that provides are excellent - from the sheer walls of Diablo Canyon, to the Pajarito Canyon and Rio Grande, to the Sangre de Cristos. While this hike is not one referenced in the literature or on-line, it is well worth the trip!

row.hikeInfo: The Galisteo Basin is a preserve just south of Santa Fe that offers multiple hiking options via numbered trail segments. The area is also well suited for mountain bikes, with relatively easy grades up and down the hills. As you hike any of the sections, the views of the mountains are splendid and in every direction - from the San Pedros, Ortiz, Sandias, Cerrillos Hills and the Sangre de Cristos to the Pecos Region, and Jemez. Even Mount Taylor is visible from the ridge tops. The trails are well-maintained and there are trail maps at many of the segment junctions. The Conservancy group is extending the available trails yearly.

row.hikeInfo: This hike is short but full of pleasant surprises, a popular site for locals. Located not far from Santa Fe, the location is well marked on most maps, and provides an ample parking area along NM56. After a short walk along the fence going south (arrows mark the way), you proceed up into the lava hills through a marked gate. Once near the top, the walk stays high along the mesa and offers some pleasant views of the area - but more amazingly, a large number of petroglyphs. Even compared to the national park system, this area is remarkable for its many close-together carvings and varieties of style - from spirals, to animals, to hands, to odd-shaped characters, including numerous Kokopelli figures. It is a very worthwhile excursion!
row.refs: 5^b^60 Hikes Within 60 Miles of Albuquerque^, Stephen Ausherman^b^New Mexico Journey Guide^, Jon Kramer and Julie Martinez^w^https://www.blm.gov/nm/st/en/prog/recreation/taos/la_cieneguilla.html^BLM Site^w^http://galisteo.nmarchaeology.org/sites/la-cieneguilla-petroglyphs.html^Galisteo Basin Archeological Sites^l^http://www.turquoisebear.com/adventures-flo-la-cieneguilla-petroglyph-site/^Turquoise Bear

row.tipsTxt: About 1.5 miles into the hike and shortly after leaving the neck of the funnel, Embudo Trail takes a left turn up an embankment. See the red flag on the interactive map referenced below. It's easy to miss this turn, as the drainage straight ahead also looks like a trail. After a few steps up the embankment, a small sign confirms that you are on Trail 193.
row.hikeInfo: Embudo, a Spanish word for 'funnel', lives up to its word as the trail winds past the narrow funnel neck and into the bowl shaped drainage. The parking area is large, but without facilities. It lies at the east end of Indian School Road, near the south end of the Sandias. The lot can get quite crowded on the weekends, as it serves numerous trails in the area. Embudo Trail is identified as Trail 193 and leads directly towards the canyon. It goes just south of a very large tank and north of a large spillway. The trail is quite wide at the beginning but soon narrows as it enters the neck of the funnel. There are numerous routes through the neck, and all require some degree of scrambling, so simply pick one that suits. Once past the neck, the trail resumes as a typical narrow track upwards into the canyon and up to a ridgetop with excellent area views. It is an out-and-back trail and could be extended by following one of the trails that intersects Embudo near its summit.
row.refs: 5^b^Sandia Mountain Hiking Guide^, by Mike Coltrin^w^http://www.sandiahiking.com/trailguide.html^Sandia Mountain Hiking Guide: Trails^w^http://www.cabq.gov/parksandrecreation/open-space/lands/sandia-foothills-open-space^Albuquerque Open Space^a^https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/new-mexico/embudo-canyon--2^AllTrails^w^https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7015149^The Hiking Project (REI Co-op)

row.tipsTxt: Many options exist for hikers of all levels. But regardless of the route, visitors should be ready to get to high ground in case of a flash flood.
row.hikeInfo:
Georgia O'Keeffe named these landscapes in the Rio Chama Valley near Abiquiu "The White Place", or in Spanish "Plaza Blanca". Visitors may recognize these sites from O'Keeffe's work or from the many motion pictures which have used them as a backdrop. This area of New Mexico is now on the grounds of the Dar Al Islam education center and mosque. Although this is private land, the center welcomes visitors who wish to hike and view the awe-inspiring landscapes. [Adapted from www.plaza-blanca.com referenced below.]

The Actual Hike Data below is for a relatively short out and back hike with little elevation gain. However, in a few spots you'll need to scramble up a short, narrow, steep drainage. The ASCHG Suggested Route under Proposed Hike Data is another alternative. Regardless of the exact route, hikers can choose to explore narrow canyons or climb up to ridge tops for expansive views.
row.refs: 4^w^http://www.plaza-blanca.com/hiking-and-fishing.html^Plaza Blanca Hiking^w^http://daralislam.org/^Dar al Islam Mosque^w^http://www.city-data.com/articles/Plaza-Blanca-Abiquiu-New-Mexico.html^Plaza Blanca History and Geology^w^http://www.aschg.org/jsp/hike.jsp?id=H10478^Albuquerque Senior Centers' Hiking Groups (ASCHG)

row.hikeInfo: This hike interconnects with several other area trails, many of which have differently named segments. The hike taken by the authors actually begins at Little Tesuque Creek and soon traverses north (Juan Trail) to a fence line, at which point the authors proceeded east (Saddleback Trail) and would have eventually connected to the Chamisa Trail, had it been further pursued. It was decided that the Chamisa Trail link would make for a great 2-car hike (stay tuned!). The on-line map reference below gives a nice overview of the area trails. Also, in "actual data" below, there is a link to a map showing two other hikes taken by the authors in this area. One of the unique features of this hike was the fact that there were multiple outstanding overlooks providing vistas south and southeast. There was even a man-made stick shelter on one of the bluffs (see photos on full-page map). The hike is well-suited to all seasons as there is ample shade for summer hikes, and the elevation is low enough in the winter to dramatically reduce snow accumulations.

row.hikeInfo: This trail is part of a system of trails embedded on the eastern slopes of the Sandia, many of which are located along NM 536. This particular hike starts near the Sulpher Canyon area, and although the authors went in mid-April, part of the access road was still blocked for the winter. This translates into an additional mile of hiking (out and back) to reach the actual trailhead of the Armijo Trail. The Armijo is relatively easy with gradual elevation change, and very well shaded. At its terminus, the tail intersects the Faulty Trail, which can be taken east to form a loop back to the trailhead of Armijo by following the Cienega Trail when Faulty intersects it. The first part of the Faulty Trail from the intersection with Armijo is somewhat steeper, and prior to its intersection with the Cienega Trail, it offers a lovely vista eastwrd, where the San Pedro Mountains can be glimpsed, along with a lovely wooded canyon. Following the Cienega to its end at a picnic area, the loop is closed by following the road back down to the Armijo trailhead.

row.hikeInfo: This portion of the Continental Divide Trail (CDT) starts at its junction with BLM 1102 near San Luis, in Cabezon country. The hike skirts the base of Deadman Peaks, offering lovely views of the valley below and out into the Cabezon Wilderness. The CDT is very well marked with cairns along the way, as well as one marking its departure from the dirt road BLM 1102. Park near the hoodoos just off 1102 where it joins with another two-track dirt road, and walk a short distance north on 1102 to the juncture with the CDT. There are some interesting rock features as well en route, including the turtle-shaped rock shown in one of the hike photos. The round-trip hike departs the CDT near its branch east from its north-bound segment. From there it is a short jaunt west to 1102 and back to the starting point. According to multiple links on the web, there is also a run or foot race held here.

row.tipsTxt: There are multiple two-track dirt roads criss-crossing the area, so be careful to have a clear plan with regard to your route. Also, there are occasions when fencing must be crossed. Generally these crossings can be navigated fairly easily and, with one exception, there is no barbed wire in the way.
row.hikeInfo: This land is part of the Open Space program, and winds gently down into Las Huertas Creek north of Placitas. There are great panoramas all along the way, with 360-degree views of the Sangre de Cristos, the Jemez, the Naciemientos, and the Sandia - with occassional views of White Mesa and Cabezon Peak, as well as some local mesas. The dry bed of Las Huertas Creek offers many interesting varieties of rocks, and the cut banks display alternating layers of cobblestones and packed sand. Most of the hike is easy - only one somewhat steep ascent on the return trip (see elevation chart). The book reference contains some interesting anecdotal history of the troubled area.
row.refs: 3^b^60 Hikes Within 60 Miles of Albuquerque^, Stephen Ausherman^a^https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/new-mexico/placitas-las-huertas-creek^AllTrails^w^https://www.trails.com/tcatalog_trail.aspx?trailid=XMR022-025^Trails.com

row.hikeInfo: This hike, just off-road US550 south of San Ysidro, is a pleasant stroll offering views of the surrounding terrain - the Jemez, White Mesa, the Sandia, and the Nacimiento Mountains. The level walk traverses a marshy area and loops to the other side along a wide arroyo covered with, what appears to be, gypsum from White Mesa. As the walk is short without elevation change, it makes for a pleasant diversion when passing through the area.

row.hikeInfo: This hike, while relatively easy, has some fascinating features: in particular the hoodoos and goblins. The location is north of the little village of Ponderosa in the Jemez Mountain Region, home of a very good winery (Ponderosa Winery) - a logical stopping place on the return trip. Much of the early hike takes you through some lovely, tall Ponderosa trees at a slow incline up to the hoodoo area. Some climbing into the hills is required to access the unusual geology (note the spikes in the elevation chart!). Note also that on the map link below: "Proposed + Actual Hike Trails", the two red triangles mark the beginning and end points of the area in which the goblins are to be found. Continuing to follow the dirt jeep track after the 'hairpin turn' near the end of the goblin area results in a moderate climb up to a ridge where there are some very nice views of the Ponderosa Valley. Due to it's remoteness, at least during the Spring when the authors went, there are few fellow hikers. There is a campground not far from the pullover-parking, which may feed additional activity in the Summer.

row.tipsTxt: The trails in this area are often unmarked, or markers have been destroyed over time. It is highly recommended to have a defined route for travel. Often there are criss-crossing trails, or sudden turns on the trail you are following that branch off somewhat unexpectedly. There are also sections of Mano that can be rather steep.
row.hikeInfo: This hike traverses a section of the South Sandias that is somewhat less frequently used, but not devoid of fellow hikers. It begins by following the same trail section utilized by the Embudo Trail, then branches southward. The trail proceeds slightly uphill following the power lines. All along the way, there are great views of the Albuquerque Valley and points north and south. After scaling a steep section, the trail levels out and affords a quiet 'backwater' scenic area nestled alongside the mountain. It continues up to a 'saddle' between foothills where the views can be extended eastward, and parts of I-40 can be seen though the pass. All in all, though sometimes a bit of a workout, the hike is a worthwhile scenic venture into the southern portions of the Sandias.
row.refs: 5^b^Sandia Mountain Hiking Guide^, Mike Coltrin^w^http://www.sandiahiking.com/trailguide.html#mano^Sandia Mountain Hiking Guide: Trails^w^http://www.mapmyhike.com/us/sandia-heights-nm/sandia-foothills-mano-trail-hike-route-174584374^Map My Hike^w^https://www.newscastic.com/news/a-dozen-abq-hiking-trails-you-havent-tried-yet-2677868/^NewsCastic^g^https://www.meetup.com/hiking-204/events/12844046/^Albuquerque Hiking Group

row.hikeInfo: The trail starts right at the top of Albuquerque's Tram Lift Station Lower Parking Lot and heads north. The trail winds through the foothills, with some minor ups and downs, to the La Luz Trail. From here, the hiker may return to the start or pick some other options as did the authors. Just prior to the juncture with La Luz, the 'Old La Luz' trail, infrequently used and much steeper with occasional spots where the purchase becomes narrow (not suited for children or pets), veers upward. This trail can be used to make a loop with the newer La Luz, as the two join about 2 miles up. To form a loop, take either of the two La Luz trails to their meeting point then return down the other leg, taking the Tramway Trail back to the start. Near the point where the trails merge, a side trail heads west along a ridge offering a good view of La Cueva Canyon. While part of the Tramway Trail skirts some developments, the trail is never too close, nor in view of homes for any significant distance.

row.tipsTxt: Hiker beware! There are some very steep sections to this hike, and the footing is poor, with loose rock and gravel on the surface. The point of descent to the river does not appear passable until you begin to go down and find a way from the flat-top mesa to the Santa Fe River canyon below - via very steep slopes. The photo of the petroglyph on the geomap marks the point. A good verbal description of this point is provided in the book referenced below.
row.hikeInfo: This tract of BLM land is accessed directly across from mailbox 42 on the Camino Capilla Vieja (CR54) about 0.4 miles from the intersection with CR548 (Entrada La Cienega). There is room for only two cars, and the access is provided through an opening in the fence. This hike, though relatively short, can be challenging (see tips, above). While the views are nice, they might not be worth the effort for the casual hiker.

row.tipsTxt: The route up to the saddle is relatively relatively easy. In colder months, ice on the western section of the split can make for treacherous footing. From the saddle, hikers will encounter some steep sections with loose footing going up in either direction. Hikers can go left or right up to beautiful views.
row.hikeInfo: Black Canyon Campground is in the Santa Fe National Forest. The hike starts at the trailhead parking area just outside the campground. It proceeds up through the campground, continues up the canyon, splits briefly and comes back together. At this junction, hikers can loop back down to the start or proceed further up to a saddle overlooking the Santa Fe Watershed. At the saddle, the trail splits again. Both the left and right routes lead up steep slopes to beautiful views.

row.tipsTxt: The hike up the creek and surrounding canyon is difficult in many spots due to water crossings, steep sections, and loose footing. The trail is also difficult to discern and even non-existent for long streches.
row.hikeInfo: This hike follows a little-known trail up the Tesuque Creek South Fork. Other than the sound and sight of water and the forest setting, the hike doesn't offer much more than exercise.
